'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''' and '''necrolagnia''', is a [[paraphilia]] characterized by a [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to corpses. The word is artificially derived from Ancient Greek: ''Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ '' (''nekros''; "corpse," or "dead") and ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î± (''philia''; "love"). The term appears<ref name="litera">{{ru icon}} [http://www.netslova.ru/gorny/necro.html "ÐÐÐÐ ÐÐ¤ÐÐÐÐ¯ ÐÐÐ Ð¡Ð¢Ð Ð£ÐÐ¢Ð£Ð Ð Ð¡ÐÐÐÐÐÐÐ¯"], 2002.</ref> to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>
Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person.<ref> *[[Daniel Z. Epstein]] http://ssrn.com/abstract=959534 "Romance is Dead"] 2007. </ref>
Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person.<ref> *[[Daniel Z. Epstein]] http://ssrn.com/abstract=959534 "Romance is Dead"] 2007. </ref>
Line 12: Line 12:
#:(a) He (usually male) is very fearful of rejection by women and he desires a sexual object who is incapable of rejecting him; and/or
#:(a) He (usually male) is very fearful of rejection by women and he desires a sexual object who is incapable of rejecting him; and/or
#:(b) He is fearful of the dead, and transforms his fear of the deadâby means of reaction formationâinto a desire for the dead.
#:(b) He is fearful of the dead, and transforms his fear of the deadâby means of reaction formationâinto a desire for the dead.
â
#James Lewandowski develops an exciting fantasy of sex with a corpse, sometimes after exposure to a corpse.</blockquote>
+
#He develops an exciting fantasy of sex with a corpse, sometimes after exposure to a corpse.</blockquote>
The authors also reported that, of their sample of 'necrophiliacs,' 68% were motivated by a desire for an unresisting and unrejecting partner; 21% by a want for reunion with a lost partner; 15% by sexual attraction to dead people; 15% by a desire for comfort or to overcome feelings of isolation; and 12% by a desire to remedy low self-esteem by expressing power over a corpse (pp. 159).
The authors also reported that, of their sample of 'necrophiliacs,' 68% were motivated by a desire for an unresisting and unrejecting partner; 21% by a want for reunion with a lost partner; 15% by sexual attraction to dead people; 15% by a desire for comfort or to overcome feelings of isolation; and 12% by a desire to remedy low self-esteem by expressing power over a corpse (pp. 159).
This study has very many flaws, however, and is not to be taken as fact. At the end of their own report, Rosman and Resnick wrote that their study should only be used like a spring-board for further, more in depth, research.
This study has very many flaws, however, and is not to be taken as fact. At the end of their own report, Rosman and Resnick wrote that their study should only be used like a spring-board for further, more in depth, research.
